perturbation.original_text: 2.5      LKPL will have no liability whatsoever for any of Axiometric's                   equipment, furniture, supplies or other personal property;                   Axiometric will use the space at its sole risk.
perturbation.changed_text: 2.5      LKPL will have no liability for damage to Axiometric's equipment, furniture, supplies or other personal property arising from gross negligence or willful misconduct on the part of LKPL; Axiometric will use the space at its sole risk.
perturbation.explanation: By limiting LKPL's liability only to cases of gross negligence or willful misconduct, the contract effectively removes the implied warranty of reasonable care. Under Maryland law, landlords have a duty to exercise reasonable care for the safety of their tenants' property. This omission weakens Axiometric's protection and increases their risk, creating a legal contradiction.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Maryland law regarding landlord's duty of reasonable care.

The one (1) year limitation does not apply to claims arising from gross negligence or willful misconduct.
perturbation.explanation: By stating a fixed one-year limitation period for all claims (except non-payment), regardless of the nature of the claim, the contract could violate Maryland law. Maryland law generally allows for a three-year statute of limitations for most civil claims. While parties can contractually shorten the statute of limitations, such clauses are often strictly construed, and a court might find that a one-year limitation is unconscionable, especially for claims involving latent defects or fraud discovered long after the event. Adding the additional phrase ensures the one-year limitation period does not apply to gross negligence or willful misconduct which ensures it will not violate state law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Maryland Statute of Limitations for civil claims.

perturbation.original_text: 7.3      If suit or action is instituted to enforce any of the terms of                   this Agreement, then the prevailing party shall be entitled to                   recover from the other party such sums as the Court may                   adjudge reasonable as attorney's fees at trial on or appeal of                   such suit or action, in addition to all other sums provided by                   law.
perturbation.changed_text: 7.3      If suit or action is instituted to enforce any of the terms of this Agreement, then the prevailing party *may* be entitled to recover from the other party attorney's fees at the discretion of the Court.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'shall' to 'may' and adding 'at the discretion of the Court' significantly weakens the prevailing party's right to recover attorney's fees. While Maryland law generally allows parties to contract regarding attorney's fees, modifying 'shall' to 'may' could discourage parties, especially Axiometric, from pursuing legitimate claims, as it introduces uncertainty about recovering legal costs. This could be viewed as a violation of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, especially if LKPL has significantly more resources to litigate. It could also be seen as unconscionable if it effectively prevents Axiometric from enforcing its rights due to the risk of incurring substantial unrecoverable legal fees.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing under Maryland contract law.
